name: Essential Foundations
description: 30 essential vocabulary words every high schooler should master

words.definition: Unwilling and hesitant; disinclined.
examples: She was reluctant to speak in front of the class.
He gave a reluctant nod of agreement.

words.definition: Certain to happen; unavoidable.
examples: Change is inevitable in any growing organization.
The team's defeat seemed inevitable after they fell behind.

words.definition: Enough; adequate for the purpose.
examples: We have sufficient evidence to proceed.
Is this amount sufficient for your needs?

words.definition: Showing great variety; very different from each other.
examples: The city has a diverse population from many countries.
She has diverse interests ranging from music to science.

words.definition: Involving many carefully arranged parts; detailed and complicated.
examples: The wedding featured elaborate decorations.
He gave an elaborate explanation of the theory.

words.definition: So delicate or precise as to be difficult to detect or describe.
examples: There was a subtle hint of vanilla in the recipe.
She noticed subtle changes in his behavior.

words.definition: Important; famous; standing out so as to be easily seen.
examples: She is a prominent figure in local politics.
The building occupies a prominent position on the hill.

words.definition: Logical and consistent; able to speak clearly.
examples: She presented a coherent argument for the proposal.
He was barely coherent after the accident.

words.definition: Evoking interest or attention in an irresistible way.
examples: The documentary made a compelling case for reform.
She told a compelling story of survival.

words.definition: Widespread in a particular area or at a particular time.
examples: Smartphones are prevalent among teenagers.
The disease was prevalent in tropical regions.

words.definition: Of considerable importance, size, or worth.
examples: They made substantial progress on the project.
He inherited a substantial fortune.

words.definition: Make or become less; reduce.
examples: Nothing could diminish her enthusiasm.
The pain began to diminish after taking medicine.

words.definition: Publicly support or recommend; a person who supports a cause.
examples: She advocates for animal rights.
He is a strong advocate of education reform.

words.definition: Open to more than one interpretation; unclear.
examples: The contract contained ambiguous language.
His response was deliberately ambiguous.

words.definition: Not certain or fixed; provisional.
examples: We made tentative plans for Saturday.
She took a tentative step forward.

words.definition: Look at thoughtfully; think about deeply.
examples: He sat quietly to contemplate his options.
She contemplated a career change.

words.definition: Recognize as different; make oneself notable.
examples: Can you distinguish between the twins?
She distinguished herself in the competition.

words.definition: Suggest without directly stating.
examples: His silence seemed to imply agreement.
Are you implying that I'm wrong?

words.definition: Of great importance; critical.
examples: This is a crucial moment in the negotiations.
Sleep is crucial for good health.

words.definition: The quality of being honest and having strong moral principles.
examples: She is known for her integrity.
The integrity of the data must be maintained.

words.definition: Become aware of through the senses; understand.
examples: I perceive a change in your attitude.
She perceived the danger immediately.

words.definition: Closely connected or appropriate to what is being considered.
examples: Please keep your comments relevant to the topic.
The data is no longer relevant.

words.definition: State a fact confidently and forcefully.
examples: She asserted her innocence.
He asserted his right to speak.

words.definition: Make a statement less confused and more understandable.
examples: Could you clarify your position?
The memo helped clarify the new policy.

words.definition: Assert the opposite of a statement; be in conflict with.
examples: The witnesses contradict each other.
His actions contradict his words.

words.definition: Give special importance to something.
examples: I want to emphasize this point.
The report emphasizes the need for reform.

words.definition: Important; meaningful; large enough to be noticed.
examples: This is a significant achievement.
There was no significant difference between groups.

words.definition: Accept or admit the existence or truth of something.
examples: He acknowledged his mistake.
She refused to acknowledge his presence.

words.definition: Clearly visible or understood; obvious.
examples: The cause of the problem was apparent.
She showed no apparent concern.

words.definition: Give something to help achieve a goal or add to a result.
examples: Everyone should contribute to the discussion.
Stress can contribute to health problems.
